body:
Hi Anibal,

1. Im not entirely sure why you get a 2-tuple instead of a matrix. Is it possible for you to share the data for me to try to reproduce the issue?
2. Yes, you can safely reshape the matrix into the tensor with your described shape. First [249 x 20] matrix will correspond to the first subject, second [249 x 20] will correspond to the second subject, etc..

Hi @j1c 

Thank you for helping me!

Sure, this is the correlation matrices (subject x region x region): http://research.anibalsolon.com/cmi/mgc/corrs.npy

Hi Anibal,

It seems that not all `249 x 249` matrices are symmetric. If the matrices are not symmetric, they are considered directed graphs and will give you the left and right latent positions. This is expected behavior. Looking a little bit further into the matrices, the maximum element-wise difference of any `249 x 249` matrix and its transpose is in the order of 10^-15, suggesting either a data type casting issue (typically going from 32bit to 64bit data) or floating point arithmetic issue.

A solution is to symmeterize each matrix, cast the data to `np.float32`, or just use either `embeddings[0]` or `embeddings[1]`.
@j1c  thoughts on adding something like a `is_almost_symmetric` function up to some tolerance, and throwing a warning? I think many graphs generated from functional connectivity could have this issue
Or, we should at least clarify in the docs when one should expect a 2-tuple

i think both are good ideas!

it might even be worth including code to generate correlation matrices that
are symmetric in graspy directly,
since apparently other ways of doing it to generate legit correlation
matrices.

On Fri, Nov 9, 2018 at 11:41 AM Benjamin Pedigo <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> Or, we should at least clarify in the docs when one should expect a 2-tuple
>
> —
> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub

> or mute the thread

-- 
the glass is all full:  half water, half air.
neurodata.io

@bdpedigo @jovo out of curiousity, how does one generate non-symmetric correlation matrices (assuming no roundoff error, as seems to be the case above)? I could understand if the metric was not correlation, but your model is not multivariate normal without PSD covariance, and if non-symmetric, you are not PSD...

that said, generation of correlation matrices in python is a 1-liner that's already fairly straightforward with no hyperparameters, so I don't think there's a need to include it in graspy necessarily @jovo @j1c. Given `D` is `nxt`, to generate the pairwise correlation matrix, simply call `np.corrcoef(D)`. It could be useful to produce a doc somewhere specifically for fMRI researchers to give them initial exploratory analyses to do with `graspy` (as well as how to properly obtain graphs in there using numpy).

i would agree with you, except @Anibal Solon <Anibal.Solon@childmind.org> is
good, and he did it in a way that breaks us,
we don't write code based on what we think other people *should* need,
we write our code based on experience of what other people actually *do*
need.
@Anibal Solon <Anibal.Solon@childmind.org> , and i assume others, would
benefit,
so it is a no brainer to include.

that said, i am also curious what anibal did.  i'm guessing something in
cpac :)
